text: a few weeks ago I went to Bonnaroo which

takes place in the Congo and showcases
the war that is happening there as well
as the activists that are working to
make it a better place what I learned
from this documentary that is
super-important that I had no idea about
beforehand yet is something that's going
to definitely affect my decisions in the
future going forward is something called
conflict minerals conflict minerals are
made up of tungsten tin Tangela and gold
and are used to make up so much of our
technology that we use every single day
these conflict minerals are being mined
in places like the Congo and these mines
are controlled by corrupt military who
are using these funds that they're
making from exporting these minerals to
fund conflict and commit human rights
violations when Intel found out about
these conflict minerals and how a lot of
the minerals that they were getting from
the Congo where conflict minerals they
decided not to pull out of the Congo
which would ultimately cause actually
more harm to just pull out and say we're
not going to deal with you anymore
instead they decided to stay and deal
with the problem in a very different way
in a more effective way until along with
some others have implemented a process
where they can validate the smelters in
the supply chain so the smelters are the
people that mined the minerals and they
know exactly where they're getting their
minerals from and they make sure they
are not conflict minerals in the
screening they announce that by the end
of this year all of Intel products will
